head.title: Make Terrorists Pay a Real Price

hedline.hl1: Make Terrorists Pay a Real Price

abstract.p: Stephen M Flatow letter responds to Oct 25 Op-Ed article by Susan and Daniel Cohen; supports Justice for Victims of Terrorism law; Flatow's daughter Alisa was killed in 1995 by Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a client of Iran (M)

block.p: Unlike Susan and Daniel Cohen (''The Bill for Terror,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 25), I am a relative newcomer to the fight against terrorism -- my 20-year-old daughter, Alisa, was killed in 1995 by the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a client of Iran.

Unlike Susan and Daniel Cohen (''The Bill for Terror,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 25), I am a relative newcomer to the fight against terrorism -- my 20-year-old daughter, Alisa, was killed in 1995 by the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a client of Iran.

Nonetheless, we share many experiences, including the frustration of dealing with a government whose goals at times appear at odds with ours. The Justice for Victims of Terrorism law, under which our government will provide compensatory damages to victims of terrorism and then seek recompense from terrorist states, brings our goals closer together. It will impose a cost on terror-sponsoring countries like Iran and Cuba by using their blocked assets as the ultimate source of compensation. The prospect of international terrorism threatens all Americans; we must be creative in the development of new ways to put a price tag on the acts of those who would harm us.
STEPHEN M. FLATOW Jersey City, Oct. 25, 2000
